content:
• Wednesday, March 29, 2017
  • IDXG

    Interpace Diagnostics higher 35% on Q4 results

    • Interpace Diagnostics (NASDAQ:IDXG): Q4 EPS of $3.25
    • Revenue of $3.12M (+21.9% Y/Y)
    • Shares +35.3% AH.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 11:23 PM | 3 Comments

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5.25 p.m.: EXTR +14.7%. PRGS +6.3%. COP +6.1%. HTGM +4.7%. AREX +2.6%.
    • Top losers, as of 5.25p.m.: LULU -18.1%. TNXP -15.3%. CVE -7.1%. SIGM -6.7%. WOR -5.4%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM | 3 Comments
  • SA

    Seabridge Gold launches 1M-share bought deal offering

    • Seabridge Gold (NYSEMKT:SA) -2.5% AH after announcing a bought deal financing for 1M common shares at C$14.30/share, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 100K shares.
    • SA also announces a concurrent bought deal offering of 1M flow-through common shares at C$20/share, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 100K shares.
    • SA says it plans to use the proceeds to continue to advance the KSM and Iskut projects in British Columbia and for general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:26 PM
  • EXTR

    Extreme Networks buying Brocade data-center networking; shares +14%

    • Extreme Networks (EXTR -1.1%) has gotten an after-hours boost, up 14.2%, after news that it's buying the data-center networking business from Brocade (BRCD -0.2%).
    • The deal's contingent on a successful takeover of Brocade by Broadcom (AVGO +0.2%).
    • Extreme will pay $55M in cash -- $35M at closing, and $20M in deferred payments, along with potential performance-based payments over a five-year term.
    • The company expects the deal to be accretive to cash flow and earnings in fiscal 2018, and to generate more than $230M in incremental annualized revenue.
    • Extreme recently agreed to be stalking-horse bidder for Avaya's networking business ($200M annualized revenue expected) and last fall closed its acquisition of Zebra Technology's wireless LAN business.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:25 PM | 5 Comments
  • PRGS

    Progress Software +9.7% on Q1 beat; names new CFO

    • Progress Software (PRGS +1.3%) has traded up 9.7% after hours after fiscal Q1 results where it beat on top and bottom lines and named a new chief financial officer.
    • The company tapped Paul Jalbert as the new CFO, and he immediately pointed to strong free cash flow of $43M, up from $22.7M, "driven largely by collections that resulted in an excellent DSO performance, a testament to the quality of our products and services."
    • Revenue inched up slightly to $91.2M, while operating margin climbed to 30% from a previous 24%.
    • Cash, equivalents and short-term investments came to $264.2M. DSO was 48 days vs. a year-ago 59 days, and 50 days at the end of the previous quarter.
    • For Q2, it's guiding to revenues of $89M-$92M (slightly below consensus for $93.1M) and non-GAAP EPS of $0.35-$0.37 (vs. consensus for $0.37). For the full year, it still sees revenue of $388M-$396M (vs. $391M expected) and EPS of $1.64-$1.69 (vs. consensus for $1.66).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:59 PM | 1 Comment
  • ANTH

    Anthera's Sollpura on par with Pancreaze in extension phase of late-stage study in certain CF patients; shares ahead 9% after hours

    • Nano cap Anthera Pharmaceuticals (OTC:ANTH) is up 9% after hours on robust volume in response to its announcement of positive results from the extension phase of a Phase 3 non-inferiority clinical trial, SOLUTION, assessing Sollpura (liprotamase) compared to Pancreaze in cystic fibrosis (CF) patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI).
    • During the extension period (week 7 through week 20) all patients in both groups maintained their weight. Increases in weight and height were observed in patients less than 17 years of age in both cohorts. Sollpura was well-tolerated throughout the treatment period.
    • Sollpura is a non-porcine pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy (PERT) containing a proprietary engineered cross-linked formulation of crystalline lipase, crystalline protease and amorphous amylase. The company says its solubility and stability offers a more patient-friendly alternative for those who cannot swallow multiple pills or require gastric tubes in order to maintain their nutritional health.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:51 PM | 11 Comments
  • EXFO

    EXFO fiscal Q2 revenues miss despite 12% growth

    • EXFO (EXFO +3.5%) is off 15% in a light postmarket trade following fiscal Q2 results where revenues missed slightly despite gains of 12%.
    • EBITDA fell to $4.9M from $5.3M, missing an expected $5.3M; it made up 8.1% of sales.
    • Bookings were $55.9M vs. a year-ago $59.7M; book-to-bill ratio came to 0.93. Year-to-date bookings growth is up 3% Y/Y.
    • After the quarter ended, the company acquired Ontology Systems for $7.6M net of cash along with a sales-based earnout.
    • For Q3, it's expecting sales of (U.S. dollars) $58M-$63M (slightly below consensus for $64M) and EPS of -$0.02 to $0.02 (below expected $0.09).
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:35 PM | 1 Comment
  • TNXP

    Tonix Pharma readies equity offering; shares off 14% after hours

    • Tonix Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:TNXP) slumps 14% after hours on robust volume in response to its planned stock offering. Price, volume and terms have yet to be announced. Net proceeds will fund pipeline development, working capital and general corporate purposes.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:31 PM | 10 Comments
  • CVE

    Cenovus to buy ConocoPhillips' 50% stake in FCCL, other assets for C$17.7B

    • Cenovus Energy (NYSE:CVE) agrees to acquire ConocoPhillips' (NYSE:COP) 50% interest in the Foster Creek Christina Lake partnership, the companies' jointly owned oil sands venture operated by CVE, and the majority of COP's Deep Basin conventional assets in Alberta and British Columbia, for C$17.7B (US$14.1B) in cash and stock.
    • CVE says the assets have a combined forecast 2017 production of ~298K boe/day, and should result in an 18% increase in 2018 adjusted funds flow per share compared with its original 2018 forecast.
    • COP also will receive five years of uncapped contingent payments, triggered when Western Canada Select crude prices exceed C$52/bbl.
    • To help fund the deal, CVE is launching a bought-deal offering to sell 187.5M common shares at C$16/share for ~C$3B in expected gross proceeds; the underwriters will have an over-allotment option to purchase up to an additional 28.125M shares.
    • CVE -8.2%, COP +6.1% AH.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:25 PM | 65 Comments
  • SIGM

    Sigma Designs -11% as revenues disappoint

    • System-on-chip provider Sigma Designs (NASDAQ:SIGM) is off 10.9% after hours following Q4 results that missed revenue expectations after sales dropped 17%.
    • EPS was in line, though the company swung to a net loss, and non-GAAP gross margin grew to 50.6% from a previous-year 49.6%. Operating expenses fell to $26M from $27.4M.
    • The company's transitioning to an Internet-of-Things focus, says CEO Thinh Tran, and that will include a transition of development to lower-cost regions. The company's started a program to cut annual operating expenses by about 10% this year.
    • Conference call to come at 5 p.m. ET.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:16 PM
  • LULU

    Tailspin for Lululemon after warning on 'slow start' to 2017

    • Lululemon (NASDAQ:LULU) reported solid sales growth for Q4, but missed profit estimates and is rattling investors with its full-year guidance.
    • Comparable store sales rose 8% during the quarter to sail past the consensus estimate for a 5.3% rise.
    • Gross margin during the quarter came in at 54.2% vs. 53.7% expected and 50.3% a year ago.
    • Income as a percentage of revenue was up 130 bps to 24.9% of sales.
    • Lululemon ended the quarter with 406 stores open, +17 Q/Q and +43 Y/Y.
    • Looking ahead, Lululemon expects Q1 revenue of $510M to $515M vs. $553M consensus and Q1 EPS of $0.25 to $0.27 vs. $0.39 consensus. For the full year, revenue of $2.55B to $2.62B is expected vs. $2.62B consensus and EPS guidance arrives at $2.26 to $2.36 vs. $2.56 consensus. CEO Laurent Potdevin warns on the "slow start" to 2017.
    • Previously: Lululemon Athletica misses by $0.01, beats on revenue (March 29)
    • LULU -15.54% AH to $56.20 vs. a 52-week trading of 54.00 to $81.81.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:13 PM | 19 Comments
  • SNV

    Synovus in talks to buy financial arm of Cabela's - Dow Jones

    • As part of the deal, Synovus (NYSE:SNV) would then sell the credit card unit to Capital One (NYSE:COF), and keep the deposits.
    • Capital One earlier this year walked away from a deal with Cabela's (NYSE:CAB) as it didn't expect to receive regulatory approval.
    • The sale to Synovus would open the door for Cabela's acquisition by Bass Pro. Cabela's shot higher into the close, finishing ahead by 12.5%.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:12 PM | 17 Comments
  • UNH

    Hospitals and insurers under pressure on Republicans' reboot of healthcare bill

    • Hospitals and insurers continue their up-and-down behavior in response to Republican lawmakers' efforts to pass the American Health Care Act. They plan another run next week.
    • Source: Bloomberg
    • Related tickers: (UNH -1.1%)(AET -1%)(ANTM +0.2%)(CI -0.7%)(HUM -0.3%)(WCG -1.4%)(CNC +0.4%)(MOH -1.2%)(HQY +1.3%)(QHC -14.3%)(HCA -0.5%)(THC -2.3%)(UHS -0.7%)(LPNT +0.4%)(CYH -4.8%)(HCP)(SEM +1.1%)
     
     
     
     
    | 4:05 PM | 29 Comments
  • GEVO

    Gevo misses by $0.18, misses on revenue

    • Gevo (NASDAQ:GEVO): Q4 EPS of -$1.14 misses by $0.18.
    • Revenue of $5.8M (-20.5% Y/Y) misses by $1.34M.
    • Shares +13%.
    • Press Release
     
     
     
     
    | 4:01 PM | 5 Comments
  • SNAP

    Snap hits positive ground after Winter Olympics deal

    • Snap (NYSE:SNAP) has reversed field late today -- now up 1.8% after being down as much as 4% following cautious notes from Odeon and Barclays -- after news of a deal tied to the 2018 Winter Olympics.
    • The company has signed with NBCUniversal (NASDAQ:CMCSA) to become a digital home for Olympic content, including related geofilters and Snapchat "lenses." Ad commitments tied to the deal could come in the range of $50M-$75M, The Wall Street Journal reports.
    • The two had partnered last year with a deal regarding highlights for the Rio Olympics, the first time NBC allowed Olympic video off its property.
    • Expanding on that arrangement, Snapchat will also carry coverage of the Winter Games that BuzzFeed will co-produce with NBC.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:33 PM | 94 Comments
  • CRTO

    Criteo -2.1% as Goldman goes Neutral on valuation

    • Criteo (NASDAQ:CRTO) is off 2.1% today, taking some edge off a strong 2017, after a Goldman Sachs downgrade to Neutral, from Buy.
    • That run (up 21.8% YTD) has prompted the new stance, since Goldman still sees solid fundamentals at the company amid a secular shift to digital, writes analyst Heath Terry.
    • A takeout isn't likely, since Criteo provides a strategic benefit as an alternative to Google/Facebook; Terry thinks at current valuation there's a 15-30% chance it gets acquired.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:26 PM
  • BOFI

    BofI lower on bankruptcy filing; selloff overdone, says FBR

    • A bankruptcy filing alleged that a Quick Bridge loan issued through BofI (NYSE:BOFI) was invalid, but FBR's Bob Ramsey says the allegations are mostly aimed at Quick Bridge, not BofI. Further, this sort of charge from bankruptcy debtors is pretty normal.
    • He also notes the bankruptcy trustee is not a DOJ employee, so a report that this is a DOJ allegation against BofI is untrue.
    • BOFI was down double-digits earlier in the session, but has clawed back to a 4% loss.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:14 PM | 14 Comments
  • CFG

    Citizens Financial -2.5% on report of fabricated data

    • Part of the bank's turnaround plan is a program in which Citizens (CFG -2.5%) invites customers into branches for a financial checkup. According to CFG, 400K such meetings were scheduled last year.
    • In a report from the WSJ, eleven current and former branch employees across five states say they or others made up information about these meetings in order to meet aggressive goals set by the bank.
    • One former branch manager said "no one was picking up the phone" when employees were trying to make appointments, so eventually they just put random customers' names down on the appointment sheet.
    • After the fake appointment was supposed to have taken place, bankers than marked that the customer didn't show or didn't sign up for any new products.
    • Citizens says it has no data to suggest any shenanigans.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:05 PM | 2 Comments

  • Technology - Top Gainers / Losers as of 3:00 pm

    • Gainers: EXAR +22%. SITO +13%. EMAN +10%. VRNT +9%. VHC +8%.
    • Losers: QBAK -12%. MOSY -12%. NTNX -7%. SCWX -7%. QUIK -7%.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:02 PM | 12 Comments
  • USCR

    U.S. Concrete's recent weakness a buying opportunity, DA Davidson says

    • U.S. Concrete (USCR +3.4%) is higher after DA Davidson analyst Brent Thielman says its disclosure last week of an auditor change and the CFO's resignation are unrelated and raise unnecessary concerns, and that it could not have hired Ernst & Young if a material concern had existed.
    • According to The Fly.com, Thielman also says USCR has significant capital available to deploy, and could attract a new DVO with more extensive M&A and/or materials industry experience.
    • The firm rates USCR as a Buy with an $80 price target, and views the recent pullback as a buying opportunity.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:55 PM | 1 Comment
  • EGO

    Eldorado Gold +9% on better Olympias sales terms; Canaccord ups to Buy

    • Eldorado Gold (EGO +9.2%) is upgraded to Buy from Hold with a $5.50 price target at Canaccord Genuity after the company said it had received multiple tenders for significantly better concentrate sales terms for the phase two expansion of its Olympias project in Greece.
    • "Underground development appears to be well advanced to support expanded production levels," Canaccord's Tony Lesiak writes, adding that commercial production at Olympias is expected to begin in H2 2017.
    • As a result of the improved terms and current zinc prices, the firm expects EGO's cash operating costs to come in below current company guidance of $230-$370/oz. from 2018 to 2022.
    • Also, Credit Suisse raises its EGO stock price target to $5.25 from $4.75 while maintaining an Outperform rating.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:25 PM | 6 Comments
  • INFN

    MKM: Rest of Street too bullish on Infinera; shares -1.7%

    • Optimism around Infinera (INFN -1.7%) is running ahead of course, argues MKM Partners' Michael Genovese, reiterating a Neutral stance on the stock.
    • The key long haul fiber market has just passed a spending cycle, he notes, and expectations for a burgeoning "metro" fiber market are hot: "Success in next-gen Metro will be key, but we think it would be dangerous for investors to assume that once new Metro products come out it will be off to the races for revenues."
    • Genovese has a fair value estimate of $9, about 14% below today's price.
    • There's improvement ahead for sure, Genovese says: "The bull case is revenues and GMs are bottoming in 1Q17, and financials should sharply improve from here driven by the new ICE4 chipset and multiple new DCI, Metro and LH product launches in 2017. We agree revenues and margins should sequentially improve through 2017, but we disagree about the magnitude."
    • Earlier this month, Goldman Sachs boosted Infinera to Buy, expecting new products to continue momentum from some revenue recognition boosts coming in Q2.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:11 PM
  • DXLG

    Apparel stocks get their day in the sun

    • Border tax fears continue to seep away from the retail sector as more members of the GOP indicate that they support a more traditional style of tax reform. The recent failure of President Trump to get a healthcare bill passed also is indicative of how tricky it might be to see an adjusted border tax policy approved by Congress.
    • Couple with some recent favorable macroeconomic news, investors are showing some confidence in companies that make and sell clothes.
    • The group of apparel-focused stocks moving higher today include Destination XL Group (DXLG +8%), Dillard's (DDS +6.7%), Ascena Retail Group (ASNA +6.6%), Stage Stores (SSI +5.7%), J.C. Penney (JCP +7.3%), Hibbett Sports (HIBB +5.1%), Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF +4.3%), Express (EXPR +4%), Kohl's (KSS +3.8%), Land's End (LE +3.4%), Cherokee (CHKE +6.9%), Gap (GPS +4%), G-III Apparel (GIII +6.1%), Oxford Industries (OXM +1.8%), Crocs (CROX +3.5%), Fossil (FOSL +2.1%), Vera Bradely (VRA +2%), Sequential Brands Group (SQBG +2.2%)  and Urban Outfitters (URBN +4.1%).
     
     
     
     
    | 2:08 PM | 24 Comments

  • Energy/Materials - Top Gainers / Losers as of 2:00 pm

    • Gainers: NADL +21%. ROYT +19%. TRCH +15%. BRS +12%. HOS +11%.
    • Losers: GBR -22%. MPVD -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:01 PM
  • ATHX

    William Blair's initiation of Athersys gets even wilder; shares up 25%

    • via Notable Calls
    • "We view Athersys (ATHX +25.4%) as one of the most asymmetric opportunities in the biotech universe," says William Blair. "Particularly given the clearly defined path to approval."
    • Noting a pristine safety profile and a SPA agreed upon with the FDA, Blair says should MultiStem hit on its primary endpoint in the MASTERS-2 study, the product will be approved.
    • With one of the world's largest markets then opened up with little competitive pressure, Athersys could be a 50x-100x-bagger in the next two years.
    • Previously: William Blair sees Athersys as nearly a 10-bagger; shares +16% in post-market (March 28)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:49 PM | 36 Comments
  • MYL

    Mylan's generic version of GSK's Advair rejected by FDA; shares down 2%

    • Mylan (MYL -2.2%) has received a complete response letter from the FDA for its abbreviated new drug application for GlaxoSmithKline's (GSK +0.6%) Advair Diskus.
    • The company is in the process of reviewing the CRL.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:32 PM | 19 Comments
  • NRG

    NRG Energy raised to Buy from Neutral at Goldman Sachs

    • NRG Energy (NRG +3.5%) is upgraded to Buy from Neutral with a $26 price target at Goldman Sachs, seeing another 40%-plus upside from current levels even after shares have surged 60% in the past six months.
    • Among the reasons for the upgrade, Goldman cites cost management with reductions of ~$180M by 2018 and $250M by 2019, the implementation of a "shrink and grow" strategy aimed at deleveraging, and a potential restructuring of NRG's GenOn subsidiary.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:21 PM | 5 Comments
  • BHC

    Buying picks up (a bit) in Valeant on increased wiggle room on debt payments; shares ahead 4%

    • Valeant Pharmaceuticals (VRX +4.3%) perks up modestly higher volume as investors move back into the stock as more details emerge on its efforts to secure more favorable debt repayment terms.
    • In an 8-K filed today, it reports that it has completed an amendment to its credit revolver extending the maturity date of $1.19B in borrowings to the earlier of April 20, 2020 or 91 days prior to the scheduled maturity of any series or tranche of term loans under its 2012 Credit Agreement, certain unsecured debt and borrowings in excess of $750M. The debt was due on April 20, 2018.
    • The company paid a 0.125% fee to lenders execute the change.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:04 PM | 144 Comments
  • FTNT

    Fortinet up 4% after Baird upgrade

    • Analyst Jayson Noland sees about 33% upside for the stock, noting the security market has been consolidating, a trend that can be expected to continue, he believes.
    • Fortinet (FTNT +4.3%) had 13.5% of the firewall market last year, says Noland, putting it fourth in line behind Cisco, Palo Alto, and Check Point.
    • Noland upgrades to Outperform with $50 price target.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM | 2 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: TNXP +40%. ATHX +24%. VRTX +23%. XELB +23%. EXAR +22%. PFMT +20%. PN +20%. NADL +19%. ROYT +19%. GLA +14%
    • Losers: ATOS -27%. DFFN -23%. GBR -22%. SSH -18%. PTX -17%. HPJ -15%. AKER -15%. CBIO -15%. MOSY -14%. QHC -12%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:50 PM | 1 Comment
  • WBMD

    WebMD starts process of selling itself, shares up 4%

    • Investors sense a deal to acquire WebMD (WBMD +4.1%) may be afoot. Shares have perked up in the last hour with volume trending higher. Last month, the company began the process of evaluating strategic options to boost shareholder value.
    • Source: CNA Finance
    • Previously: WebMD to explore strategic alternatives; shares up a fraction after hours (Feb. 16)
     
     
     
     
    | 12:28 PM | 1 Comment
  • WBMD

    WebMD reportedly starts sale process; up 5%

    • According to dealReporter, the company has reached out to potential buyers, with a hoped-for price in the 12x-13x EBITDA range.
    • WBMD +5%
     
     
     
     
    | 12:23 PM

  • Consumer - Top Gainers / Losers as of 12:00 pm

    • Gainers: XELB +23%. WKHS +13%. SYPR +11%. THST +6%. SANW +6%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:00 PM
  • VEDL

    Vedanta's Agarwal says no plans to buy Anglo American assets in South Africa

    • Vedanta (VEDL +1.5%) Chairman Anil Agarwal says he had no plans to buy assets in South Africa from Anglo American (OTCQX:AAUKF, OTCPK:AAUKY) or push for a board seat, two weeks after announcing plans to buy a 13% stake in the miner.
    • Agarwal said this month that he would buy a stake of as much as 2B in Anglo but through his family trust rather than VEDL.
    • "I believe in the management, I believe in the company... I am not an activist," Agarwal says of his potential role as an Anglo shareholder, and says he has "no agenda" to seek a board position.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:57 AM | 1 Comment
  • PULM

    Pulmatrix perks up 8% on rumored Mylan interest

    • Nano cap Pulmatrix (PULM +7.5%) shows some life on rumored interest by collaboration partner Mylan N.V. (MYL -0.8%) in a takeover bid.
    • Mylan had an option on the ex-U.S. rights to COPD candidate PUR0200 but did not exercise it.
    • Previously: Pulmatrix inks development deal with Mylan (June 16, 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:55 AM | 18 Comments
  • GEGYF

    Reuters: Genel Energy CFO to step down, as chairman search continues

    • Genel Energy (OTCPK:GEGYF -4.4%) is bracing for the departure of its CFO while still struggling to find a replacement for Chairman Tony Hayward, who plans to step down in June, Reuters reports.
    • CFO Ben Monaghan, a former senior banker who joined Genel in 2015, is expected to leave after Hayward's departure but before the end of the year, according to the report.
    • Genel's market value already had collapsed to a record low yesterday after announcing a second downward revision of reserves at the company's flagship Taq Taq field in Kurdistan.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:46 AM
  • SO

    Southern Co. CEO to ask Toshiba to help complete Georgia reactors

    • Southern Co. (SO) CEO Tom Fanning says he will ask Toshiba (OTCPK:TOSBF -1.5%) to honor what he says is a commitment to complete two nuclear reactors in Georgia after lead contractor Westinghouse filed for bankruptcy protection.
    • Ahead of talks with Toshiba and Japanese government officials today, Fanning tells WSJ that the Vogtle project has the support of the U.S. administration as a direct employer of 5K people and a creator of 30K jobs throughout the supply chain.
    • “The commitments are not just financial and operational, but there are moral commitments as well,” Fanning says.
    • Toshiba and its creditors likely will see it differently: Toshiba says it will honor ~¥650B ($5.9B) in Westinghouse obligations it had guaranteed, but that it plans to exit the business of building nuclear plants and does not expect further losses.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:31 AM | 26 Comments
  • PACB

    Cowen bullish on growth of next-gen sequencing, says Pac Bio's systems best for small volume work, shares ahead 12%

    • Pacific Biosciences of California (PACB +12.4%) perks up on more than a 60% spike in volume. Earlier today, Cowen and Company released the results of a 51-lab survey revealing a bullish environment for next-generation sequencing demand, possibly up 80% this year.
    • Cowen says PACB's sequencing franchise is "making steady improvements" and generating more interest. It adds that the company's gear is best for small volume work with "confidence building." Sequencing an entire genome for $1,000 should be attainable on a PACB system by the end of next year.
    • Source: Bloomberg
    • Related tickers: (ILMN -0.5%)(QGEN -1%)(TMO -0.5%)(NSTG -0.1%)
     
     
     
     
    | 11:24 AM | 44 Comments
  • NTNX

    Nutanix lockup expiration presses shares, -7.6%

    • Nutanix (NASDAQ:NTNX) is 7.6% lower with the arrival of a six-month post-IPO lockup expiration, allowing employees to sell a large chunk of outstanding shares, and volume has already quadrupled the stock's daily average in the first 90 minutes of trading.
    • After hitting a high of $46.78 in its first few days of trading in October, the stock has now slid 61% since, to $18.42 (but still 15% above IPO price).
    • Meanwhile, the shares look cheap to Piper Jaffray with the lockup expiration creating an opportunity. The current valuation is "compelling" even with selling pressure, with the company's enterprise value to 2018 sales multiple around 1.9 times, vs. peers' 3.7 times.
    • Analyst Andrew Nowinski has an Overweight rating and $36 price target, implying 95% upside from today's depressed level.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM | 13 Comments

  • Healthcare - Top 5 Gainers / Losers as of 11:00 am

    • Gainers: TNXP +39%. NYMX +28%. VRTX +24%. INNL +18%. PACB +16%.
    • Losers: ATOS -26%. RTTR -22%. DFFN -21%. CBIO -18%. SSH -17%.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:00 AM
  • LL

    Lumber Liquidators +7% after positive home sales data

    • Lumber Liquidators (NYSE:LL) is up 6.71% on strong early volume.
    • A positive report from the National Association of Realtors on pending home sales could be bringing in some buyers.
    • "Buyers came back in force last month as a modest, seasonal uptick in listings were enough to fuel an increase in contract signings throughout the country," notes NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun.
    • Previously: Pending home sales pop in February (March 29)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:56 AM | 22 Comments
  • BRS

    Bristow +8% presenting at energy conference

    • Expects challenging market conditions and offshore E&P spend to be down again in FY18, but "green shoots are beginning to appear."
    • Leased aircraft will offset rent savings from returned aircraft in the short term.
    • Improving liquidity runway by $630M. Continues to reduce incremental lease costs.
    • Employing aviation competencies to diversify complementary and growing businesses.
    • Notes successful execution of FY17 Action Plan and recent tenders as evidence the company can maintain its leadership position.
    • BRS shares are up almost 8% on the news.
    • See full presentation here
     
     
     
     
    | 10:52 AM

    Under Armour heads higher amid trader chatter of PE deal

  • INNL

    Innocoll clarifies data needed to support refiling of U.S. marketing application for XARACOLL, resubmission possible by year-end; shares ahead 34%

    • Innocoll Holdings (INNL +34.3%) jumps on triple normal volume in response to its announcement of a clear regulatory path to resubmitting its New Drug Application (NDA) with the FDA seeking approval of XARACOLL (bupivacaine HCl collagen-matrix implant) for the treatment of postsurgical pain. The company received a Refusal to File (RTF) letter in December 2016 in response to its initial submission. An RTF means that the filing is not complete enough to review.
    • Minutes from the Type A meeting specified the following requirements for an acceptable NDA: an additional short-term pharmacokinetic study, several short-term nonclinical toxicology and biocompatibility studies, additional manufacturing information to address the new combination product designation and other chemistry, manufacturing and control (CMC) information.
    • The company believes that it can complete the work and refile the NDA by the end of the year if it has the necessary funding.
    • Previously: Innocoll gets refusal to file letter from FDA on XARACOLL; -52% after hours (Dec. 29, 2016)
     
     
     
     
    | 10:06 AM | 7 Comments

  • SUNW

    Sunworks +5% with Q4 revenue beat, record backlog

    • Sunworks (NASDAQ:SUNW) has come out of the open up 5.1% following Q4 earnings where it edged revenue expectations and replaced its chief executive.
    • The company named Charles Cargile its CEO, replacing James Nelson, who will continue on as chairman of the board.

    • The company is forecasting a profit for the full year with revenues increasing more than 30%; it expects higher backlog both Y/Y and sequentially at the end of Q1.
    • Conference call to come at 10 a.m. ET.

  • SGMO

    Sangamo's ZFP-TF gene regulating technology shows significant effect on tau expression in preclinical testing; shares up 12% premarket

    • Sangamo Therapeutics (NASDAQ:SGMO) heads north 12% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement of encouraging preclinical data related to its zinc finger protein transcription factor (ZFP-TF)-mediated gene regulation technology.
    • In animal model testing, ZFP-TF showed a significant reduction in tau mRNA and tau protein expression, the first evidence of a tau-lowering agent showing efficacy on neuritic dystrophy in an amyloid mouse model of Alzheimer's disease (AD). The data were presented at the 13th International Conference on Alzheimer's & Parkinson's Diseases in Vienna, Austria.
    • Lowering tau protein is currently the "big hope" in treating AD since the amyloid plaque approach has failed to bear fruit.
     
     
     
     
    | 9:21 AM

  • RTTR

    Ritter Pharma's lactose intolerance candidate RP-G28 shows positive effect in mid-stage study but only after excluding bad data; shares down 7% premarket

    • Results from a Phase 2b/3 clinical trial assessing Ritter Pharmaceuticals' (NASDAQ:RTTR) RP-G28 in people with lactose intolerance showed an encouraging treatment benefit, evidenced by a reduction in symptoms across a range of outcome measures, but only after excluding data from one center.
    • The 377-subject Phase 2b stage met its primary endpoint showed a statistically significantly larger responder group (40%) who received RP-G28 compared to placebo (26%) (p=0.0159). The difference in the number of responders in the high-dose group versus placebo was also statistically significant (p=0.0294) as was the low-dose group (p=0.0434).
    • The primary analysis (n=296) excluded one trial site due to "significant irregularities."
    • The results from the entire study population (n=368), including the rogue site, fell short of statistical significance (p=0.0618).
    • The company plans to meet with the FDA in an End-of-Phase 2 meeting during which it expects to clarify the design of a confirmatory Phase 3 study.
    • RP-G28, a highly purified galactooligosaccharide, is designed to stimulate the growth of lactose-metabolizing bacteria in the colon. If approved, it will be the first drug cleared by the FDA for the indication.
    • Shares are down 7% premarket on robust volume.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:49 AM

  • VRTX

    Vertex Pharma's tezacaftor/ivacaftor combo successful in two late-stage studies; shares ahead 17% premarket

    • Vertex Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:VRTX) is up 17% premarket on increased volume in response to its announcement of positive results from two Phase 3 clinical trials assessing the combination of tezacaftor and ivacaftor in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF).
    • The 24-week EVOLVE study evaluated the combination in CF patients with two copies of the F508del mutation. It met the primary endpoint of a statistically valid improvement in lung function from baseline compared to placebo (p<0.0001).
    • EXPAND, an eight-week crossover study, assessed the combination in CF patients with one copy of the F508del mutation and some CFTR function. The study also met its primary endpoint of a statistically valid improvement in lung function from baseline compared to placebo (p<0.0001).
    • The company plans to file marketing applications in the U.S. and Europe in Q3.
     
     
     
     
    | 8:22 AM

  • ACOR

    Long-term safety data positive for Acorda's inhalable Parkinson's candidate CVT-301; shares ahead 1% premarket

    • Acorda Therapeutics (NASDAQ:ACOR) is up 1% premarket, albeit on only 45 shares, on the heels of its announcement of positive long-term safety data from two studies of CVT-301, an inhaled formulation of levodopa for the treatment of OFF periods in Parkinson's disease patients.
    • The two studies, CVT-301-005 and CVT-301-004E, involve ~700 subjects.
    • Data at week 52 in study 005 showed no statistical difference in lung function compared to control.
    • There was no control arm in study 004E. 49 participants completed their week 52 visit with no safety signals observed.
    • The most common adverse events in any study arm were cough (12.9%), nasopharyngitis (6.3%), dyskinesia (5.5%), fall (5.2%) and bone fracture (5.2%). There was one death (downing) judged unrelated to the study drug.
    • Data from both studies will be submitted for presentation at a future medical meeting.
    • The company plans to file an NDA next quarter and an MAA in Europe by year end.
    • Previously: Acorda's CVT-301 successful in late-stage PD study; U.S. marketing application slated for Q2; shares up 13% premarket (Feb. 9)
     
     
     
     
    | 7:57 AM
